trans-unit.source: Provides functionality required by all components.
<xref:System.ComponentModel.Component> is the default implementation of <xref:System.ComponentModel.IComponent> and serves as the base class for all components in the common language runtime.
You can contain components in a container.
In this context, containment refers to logical containment, not visual containment.
You can use components and containers in a variety of scenarios, both visual and non visual.
<xref:System.Windows.Forms.Control?displayProperty=fullName> inherits from <xref:System.ComponentModel.Component>, the default implementation of <xref:System.ComponentModel.IComponent>.
A component interacts with its container primarily through a container-provided <xref:System.ComponentModel.ISite>, which is a repository of container-specific per-component information.
Represents the method that handles the <xref href="System.ComponentModel.IComponent.Disposed"></xref> event of a component.
When you create a <xref:System.ComponentModel.IComponent.Disposed> delegate, you identify the method that handles the event.
To associate the event with your event handler, add an instance of the delegate to the event.
The event handler is called whenever the event occurs, unless you remove the delegate.
For more information about event handler delegates, see [NIB: Events and Delegates](http://msdn.microsoft.com/en-us/d98fd58b-fa4f-4598-8378-addf4355a115).
Gets or sets the <xref href="System.ComponentModel.ISite"></xref> associated with the <xref href="System.ComponentModel.IComponent"></xref>.
Sites can also serve as a repository for container-specific, per-component information, such as the component name.
The <xref href="System.ComponentModel.ISite"></xref> object associated with the component; or `null`, if the component does not have a site.
